newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada bonds close firmer, outperform U.S. issues.
newsitem.headline: Canada bonds close firmer, outperform U.S. issues.

text.p: Canadian bonds closed firmer in quiet trade on Monday, with spreads to U.S. long bonds widening amid waning concern about a possible U.S. rate hike and a stronger Canadian dollar, analysts said.

"There was a really solid bid under this market," said Hank Cunningham, director of fixed-income research with First Marathon Securities Ltd. "The dollar has finally turned some corners here, so I think that's helped more than anything else."
Canada's 30-year benchmark bond rose C$0.15 to C$111.32 to yield 7.045 percent.
The U.S. 30-year bond rose 1/32 to yield 6.87 percent. The spread between the two bonds narrowed to 18 basis points from 19 basis points at the close of trading on Friday.

"The market is coming to grips (with the fact) that there's a smaller and smaller probability of the Fed going in May and the implications for the Canadian dollar," said one Toronto-based bond trader. "On top of that the technicals have been great. There's been buying and very little selling."
Canadian and U.S. fixed-income markets saw sharp gains last week, with the Canadian market closing stronger for four out of five sessions.

Canadian bonds rallied last week amid economic reports that reduced expectations of tightening by the Fed. Declining expectations for a rate hike also benefited the currency, which firmed further today to close below C$1.38 (US$0.7246)

Analysts said Canadian markets would likely trade sideways for the early part of this week amid a lack of significant U.S. economic data. Canadian economic reports this morning on foreign reserves and building permits had little to no impact on bonds, dealers said.
In other prices, Canada's 10-year benchmark bonds rose C$0.15 to C$103.65 to yield 6.475 percent. The U.S. bond rose 1/32 to yield 6.64 percent.
The negative spread between the bonds widened to 17 basis points from 15 basis points on Friday.
The three-month cash T-bill yielded 2.97 percent against its U.S. equivalent, which yielded 5.11 percent.
